name: Holy Water
description: Water blessed by a priest or deacon, used for making the Sign of the Cross, blessing persons and homes, and recalling Baptism. Attested in the Church by the 2nd–3rd centuries; formulas varied regionally. Variations: Easter Water (Easter Vigil) and water with blessed salt.

name: Rosary
description: Beads used to count prayers and meditate on the mysteries of Christ. Tradition links popularization to St. Dominic (13th c.), though it developed from earlier prayer practices. Forms: Dominican Rosary, Franciscan Crown, many chaplets.

name: Brown Scapular
description: A reduced form of the Carmelite habit worn as a sign of devotion to Our Lady of Mount Carmel. Widely adopted from the 13th century onward. Other scapulars exist with distinct promises and spirituality.

name: Miraculous Medal
description: Revealed to St. Catherine Labouré in 1830 (Paris), bearing symbols of Mary's intercession and Christ's redemption. Spread rapidly for its associated graces. Designs and inscriptions vary by language/region.

name: Crucifix
description: A cross with the corpus of Jesus, used since early Christianity as a reminder of the Passion. Found in churches, homes, and worn as pendants. Notable forms include the San Damiano cross and Byzantine styles.

name: Saint Benedict Medal
description: A devotional medal bearing initials of Latin prayers associated with St. Benedict. Promoted especially since the 17th c.; the Jubilee Medal (1880) standardized the design. Used with faith for protection.

name: Holy Cards
description: Small images of Christ, the Virgin Mary, or saints—often with prayers—popular since the 19th–20th c. with advances in printing. Used as keepsakes, catechetical aids, and memorials.

name: Blessed Salt
description: Salt blessed with particular prayers, recalling biblical symbolism of preservation and covenant. Traditionally mixed with holy water or sprinkled for protection and sanctification.

name: Incense
description: Resins burned as a sign of prayer rising to God (Ps 141:2). Used in East and West from antiquity. Blends vary by tradition; usage is governed by liturgical norms.

name: Blessed Candle
description: Candles blessed on feast days (notably Candlemas, Feb 2) symbolize Christ the Light. Used in processions, blessings, and home devotion. Beeswax content and decoration can differ.

name: Oil of the Sick (Oleum Infirmorum)
description: Olive or other plant oil sanctified by the bishop for the Sacrament of the Anointing of the Sick. As a sacred matter used in a Sacrament, it is distinct yet historically connected to blessed oils used devotionally.

name: Saint Medals (various)
description: Medals depicting particular saints (e.g., St. Michael, St. Joseph) worn as reminders of their intercession. Designs differ by culture; inscriptions often localize prayers or titles.
